name.text: Congruence in a Parallelogram with Parallel Segments

questiontext.text:
In the figure below, {@letter@}{@letter1@}{@letter3@}{@letter2@} is a parallelogram. Point {@letter4@} lies on {@letter@}{@letter2@} and point {@letter5@} lies on {@letter1@}{@letter3@}. The line {@letter1@}{@letter4@} is parallel to {@letter2@}{@letter5@}. Are triangles \( \triangle {@letter@}{@letter1@}{@letter4@} \, \text{and} \, \triangle {@letter3@}{@letter2@}{@letter5@}\) congruent?

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-1, 6, 9, -2], axis: false, showCopyright: false, showNavigation: false }); /* Base points for the parallelogram */ var A = board.create('point', [0, 4], {name: '{#letter#}', fixed: true}); var B = board.create('point', [1, 0], {name: '{#letter1#}', fixed: true}); var D = board.create('point', [6, 4], {name: '{#letter2#}', fixed: true}); /* Construct C so that ABCD is a parallelogram */ var C = board.create('point', [ function(){ return B.X() + (D.X() - A.X()); }, function(){ return B.Y() + (D.Y() - A.Y()); } ], {name: '{#letter3#}', fixed: true}); /* Draw parallelogram sides */ board.create('segment', [A, B]); board.create('segment', [B, C]); board.create('segment', [C, D]); board.create('segment', [D, A]); /* Points E on AD and F on BC */ var E = board.create('point', [ function(){ return (A.X() + D.X())/2; }, function(){ return (A.Y() + D.Y())/2; } ], {name: '{#letter4#}', fixed: true}); var F = board.create('point', [ function(){ return (B.X() + C.X())/2; }, function(){ return (B.Y() + C.Y())/2; } ], {name: '{#letter5#}', fixed: true}); /* Draw BE and DF (parallel lines) */ board.create('segment', [B, E], { strokeWidth: 2, strokeColor: 'black' }); board.create('segment', [D, F], { strokeWidth: 2, strokeColor: 'black' }); /* Optional arrows to emphasise parallelism */ board.create('arrow', [E, D], {strokeWidth: 2}); board.create('arrow', [B, F], {strokeWidth: 2}); [[/jsxgraph]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

We are given that {@letter@}{@letter1@}{@letter3@}{@letter2@} is a parallelogram and that {@letter1@}{@letter4@} âˆ¥ {@letter2@}{@letter5@}.

Step 1: Equal angles
Since the lines {@letter1@}{@letter4@} and {@letter2@}{@letter5@} are parallel, the angles

\( \angle {@letter@}{@letter1@}{@letter4@} \, = \, \angle {@letter3@}{@letter2@}{@letter5@}\) (Opposite angles of a parallelogram).

Step 2: Equal sides
In a parallelogram, opposite sides are equal in length. Hence,

\(\quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad {@letter@}{@letter1@}= {@letter3@}{@letter2@}. \)

Step 3: Triangle congruence
We now have:

  • one pair of equal angles,
  • a second pair of equal angles (by parallel lines),
  • the included sides equal.
Therefore, \( \triangle ABE \cong \triangle CDF \) by the ASA congruence criterion.
